qas.question: What creatures are often depicted on Armenian carpets?
What two motifs were usually found in Kaptavian inscriptions?
What are the Hravard inscriptions composed of?

plausible_answers.text: the illuminated manuscripts produced in Artsakh

qas.question: What are the Hravard inscriptions similar to?
What are manuscripts separated into depending on the animals on them?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Art historian<b5_0/><a0_0/> Hravard Hakobyan notes that "Artsakh carpets occupy a special place in the history of Armenian carpet-making." Common themes and patterns found on Armenian carpets were the <b6_0>depiction of <a1_0>dragons and eagles<b6_0/><a1_0/>. They were diverse in style, rich in color and ornamental motifs, and were even separated in <b9_0>categories<b9_0/> depending on what sort of animals were depicted on them, such as artsvagorgs (<a2_0>eagle-carpets<a2_0/>), vishapagorgs (<a3_0>dragon-carpets<a3_0/>) and otsagorgs (<a4_0>serpent-carpets<a4_0/>). The rug mentioned in the Kaptavan inscriptions is composed of <b7_0>three arches, "covered with vegatative ornaments"<b7_0/>, and bears an artistic resemblance to <b8_0>the illuminated manuscripts produced in Artsakh<b8_0/>.
